content: How can I help you today?

Well, I’ve been struggling to focus lately, and it feels like everything is falling apart. My wife and I are at odds, my son is having serious behavioral issues, and I can’t seem to figure out how to help him or balance anything. It’s affecting my work, my marriage, even how I interact with my daughter. I just don’t know what to do anymore.

That sounds really overwhelming—trying to keep everything together while feeling pulled in so many directions must be exhausting. It seems like you're carrying a lot of weight with your family, your work, and trying to support your son. Can you tell me more about how all of this has been affecting you personally?

Honestly, I just feel drained all the time. I barely have enough energy to get through the day, and I’m constantly worrying about my son—whether we’re doing enough or the right things to help him. It’s like I can’t even be fully present with my wife or daughter because my mind is always elsewhere. I hate feeling this way, but I can’t seem to shake it.

That sounds really tough, feeling like you're never fully present and always weighed down by worry. It seems like you care so deeply about your family and are trying your hardest to figure things out, but the emotional toll is leaving you feeling depleted. With everything on your mind, how do you usually manage to get through each day?

I don’t even know if I’m managing, honestly. I wake up, go to work, try to get things done, but my head’s all over the place. When I’m home, I’m so focused on my son and trying to work things out with my wife that it feels like I’m just barely keeping my head above water. I used to have hobbies or things I enjoyed, but I don’t even remember the last time I felt like doing anything for myself.

It sounds like you're giving everything you have to your family and work, leaving little to no time for yourself. That level of dedication is admirable, but it also seems like it's leaving you feeling stretched thin and disconnected from the things that once brought you joy. What do you think might help you feel even a little more balanced right now?

I don’t really know. Maybe if I could figure out how to help my son, it would feel like a weight’s been lifted. But honestly, everything feels so tangled up—my marriage, my son’s issues, my own stress. I wouldn’t even know where to start.

It sounds like everything feels interconnected, like one challenge fuels the next, making it hard to see a clear way forward. You seem really focused on wanting to help your son, and that concern speaks to how much you care for your family. If you could take one small step, no matter how small, what do you think might bring even a little clarity or relief to you right now?

It’s hard to say. I guess maybe talking to someone who really understands what my son is going through? Or figuring out how my wife and I can actually work together on this instead of clashing all the time. But I’m not sure any of it would actually help.

It’s understandable to feel unsure about what will actually help, given how much is on your plate. Wanting to find someone who truly understands your son’s challenges and also working on how you and your wife can come together already shows your desire to move forward, even in the midst of the uncertainty. It sounds like these might be important pieces of the puzzle for you. What part of either of those feels most manageable or meaningful to explore first?

It’s hard to even decide. Finding someone to help my son feels urgent, but working with my wife might make everything else easier to handle. I guess if we were more on the same page, it might help us figure out better ways to support him together. But I just don’t know how to get there with her right now.

It sounds like prioritizing your relationship with your wife could be a key step toward navigating these challenges as a team, and that could potentially make finding support for your son a bit less overwhelming. It’s clear this is really important to you, and you’re already thinking about how to create a stronger foundation for your family. What do you think might help open the door to better communication or collaboration with her?

It’s hard to say. Every conversation we try to have about this ends up feeling like a fight. Maybe if we had someone to help us talk through things, it’d go better, but I don’t know if she’d want to bring another person into it. Or if it’d even work. I’m just tired of everything feeling like a losing battle.

It sounds really discouraging to feel like every effort to connect leads to more conflict, even when you’re trying so hard to make things better. Your willingness to consider getting outside help shows how deeply you value finding common ground with your wife and working together for your family. What do you think it might be like to bring up the idea of getting support with her?

I think she might be open to it, especially since she’s the one who asked me to see a counselor in the first place. But part of me is worried it’ll just stir things up even more. I guess I could at least bring up the idea and see how she feels about it.

It sounds like you’re willing to take that step, even though it feels uncertain, because strengthening that partnership with your wife matters so much to you. Bringing it up could be an important starting point to see where things stand and what might be possible together. How do you feel about trying to understand her perspective before diving into the details?

Yeah, that makes sense. I think if I focus on hearing her out first, it might help set a better tone for the conversation. I just hope it doesn’t turn into another argument, but I guess I won’t know unless I try. I can talk to her about it soon and see how it goes.

That sounds like a thoughtful approach—focusing on hearing her out and opening the conversation in a way that invites understanding. It’s clear that this relationship and your family mean a lot to you, and taking this step shows your commitment to finding a way forward. Is there anything else on your mind before you take that step with her?
I think I’m okay to end the conversation. Thank you for speaking about this with me.
